page.title: 01RURAL AREA ON MENDIP HILLS
page.content: This block lies on the northern side of the Mendip hills, the land rising steeply from 350 feet to 525 feet. The whole area is rural in appearance, no industry whatsoever: the land being mainly rough grazing enclosed by limestone walls on the flat plain on the height but generally bounded by hedges on the lowerland. Two ancient woods clothe the northern slopes, mainly coniferous and used for timber. Land is used mainly for dairy farming. A few of the fields are intensively managed grassland and occasional crops of maize for animal feed. Potatoes are grown as a cash crop by several farmers. The two small villages of Farrington Gurney (population 587) and Ston Easton (pop 501) are bisected by main roads linking Bristol, Bath, Wells and Shepton Mallett and are mainly occupied by commuters
